content.text: Select a group of resistors and assemble the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1
A, B and C are crocodile clips
• Measure and record the length \(L_0\) of the resistance wire between the ends of A and B, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Record the number \(n\) of resistors in parallel connected in the component holder
n =
Close the switch
Move C along the wire until the voltmeter reading is zero
Measure and record the distance \(L\) between A and C when the voltmeter reading is zero, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Select a different group of resistors and repeat **(b)** until you have at least six sets of values of \(n\) and \(L\)
Record your results in a table
Include values of \(\frac{1}{n}\) and \(\frac{1}{L}\) in your table
\(\square\)
\(\square\)
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{L}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{n}\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and the \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =
It is suggested that the quantities \(L\) and \(n\) are related by the equation
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants
Use your answers in **(d)(iii)** to determine the values of \(a\) and \(b\)
Give appropriate units
a =
b =
In this experiment you will investigate an electrical circuit
You are provided with several groups of resistors connected in parallel
You are provided with two pieces of wire, each labelled A, and two pieces of wire, each labelled B
Measure and record the diameter \(d_{\mathrm{A}}\) of one the pieces of wire labelled A, and the diameter \(d_{\mathrm{B}}\) of one of the pieces of wire labelled B
Place the larger glass or Perspex plate on top of the piece of graph paper, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.1
• Fill the liquid dropper with water from the beaker. Use the dropper to put a single drop of water on the plate, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(W_{\mathrm{B}}\)
percentage uncertainty =   .........
Holding the smaller plate in position, carefully pull out the two wires labelled B (leaving the wires labelled A) as shown in Fig. 2.4
• Gently press the smaller plate down onto the wires labelled A
Use the \(2\mathrm{mm}\) graph grid to determine the average width \(W_{\mathrm{A}}\) of your water drop
Remove the smaller plate and the wires
• Use a paper towel to remove all water from both plates
• Repeat **(b)** and **(d)** using a larger drop of water made using two drops from the liquid dropper
It is suggested that the relationship between \(d_{\mathrm{A}}\), \(d_{\mathrm{B}}\), \(W_{\mathrm{B}}\) and \(W_{\mathrm{A}}\) is
where \(k\) is a constant
Using your data, calculate **two** values of \(k\)
first value of \(k =\)
second value of \(k =\)
Justify the number of significant figures you have given for your values of \(k\)
Explain whether your results in **(f)**(i) support the suggested relationship
Describe **four** sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe **four** improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
You may not need to use all of the materials provided
In this experiment, you will investigate the size of a drop of liquid between two glass or perspex plates
